I ran away from my deteriorating mental health for the past 4 years through excessive gaming, porn, and junk food. I got a B.A. during that time, worked for a while, and am now starting an M.S. But I am rotting from the inside.

The only real friends I have are from in HS, and I can tell they are not going down a good path. Gaming until 3 AM most nights, drinking, working dead-end jobs. I did not make friends in college, which you can blame on the pandemic. I optimized my time to play video games and neglected every other aspect of my life.

It does not help that I developed a debilitating obsession with my ex-GF following HS and during all this time. Neither of us put much effort into the relationship; there was some intimacy, but it faded, and she left me for college. I let her walk all over me during the relationship; I was desperate and weak, and still am.

I developed a lingering resentment for her because we never had sex. As a result, I delved into increasingly degenerate porn and video games to numb my mind and soul.

I achieved just that, but the problems are still there. I am stunted socially and romantically. I've been feeling increasingly depressed and anxious. I have also had off/on bouts of erection/morning wood issues over the past couple years which has caused me tremendous anxiety (I am 22). My obsessive tendencies have only worsened, and I feel like I am becoming a hypochondriac.

I am quitting porn, exercising, and developing a healthier diet because I know things won't get better if I don't put in the work. I should see a doctor regarding my health concerns too. However, I think gaming addiction is at the heart of my issues. They have been a big part of my life since I was young, but there are many opportunities I missed out on in my adolescence because I decided to game. I didn't even get my driver's license until after HS, so I had to have my pseudo-GF pick me up to do things.

I am sick of living a numb existence. It is time to change.

The office environment is a warzone; don't you forget it. You have to be psychologically unwell in order to thrive in such an environment.

Most managers do 1/4 of the work of the floor staff yet they make at least double their salary. Don't think they're going to let you encroach upon their position without a fight.

Of course you can try to stand your ground but it will almost assuredly get worse if you do. Usually by way of the "it's all your fault" game: regardless of the extent of their role in the problem, they will somehow find a way to turn it all around on you so it's your fault and not theirs. If you want to play the corporate game then keep moving jobs every two years, even if that means you have to relocate. Wishing the best for you man.

•include a picture with your friends, preferably having fun, don't have any friends? Dogs/cats or family members also work, you want to give them the feeling that you're social/family material and not some untrustworthy loner.

>>28101536

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28101153
A job change isn't going to fix your life. You need an entire lifestyle change. I'm 26 and went through something similar around 24. I'm going to recommend something cliche, but it fucking works for reasons I will elaborate on. Get in shape. If you are fat lose weight. If you are skinny hit the gym. Yes it's a physical thing but we are mostly after the mental benefits. When you improve physically it does several things mentally (arguably it has more mental benefits than physical). First is you learn to be disciplined. This obviously effects every aspect of life. You need discipline to escape NEETdom. Next it will give you a taste of that "better life". You will see hard effort turn into tangible rewards that you can be proud of. This can set off a chain reaction into other aspects of life you feel are lacking. Next is confidence. You will be more confident in your self and your abilities and it could be enough of a boost to get you to pounce on opportunities you otherwise would have missed by being passive. Perhaps most important of all it will get you out of the house and give you a hobby that isn't doing anything for you. This can lead to meeting new people and gives you a common interest hobby that you can share and engage with most people over. Don't forget other people will treat you better too.

All of that doesn't even take into account the physical aspects that also play a role in mental health. You would likely see an increase in certain hormones such as testosterone and a decrease in things like estrogen. These hormones play a huge role in mental health and having screwed up hormones probably play a huge role in depression and the like. In my opinion physical improvement is the number one best thing you can do if you are unhappy with your life because it lays the foundation for everything else. This is coming from someone who was fat basically my entire life and was well on my way to being an eternal neet. Getting /fit/ is what saved me.

I can't read it. My specific situation will not really relate to you.

The TL;DR is that I am an /out/ist through and through and nothing is going to change that.

I was in the army before college. Biology degree. Wildly depressed, and medicated for it. In college I did an internship with a conservation agency and it was fun, but I did the "right thing" and after school I just kept pursuing my "career path." Nothing glamorous or financially enticing, mind you. At 27 I had a paradigm shift, some major life changes (sister offed herself and ended a toxic 6 year relationship) and I took some seasonal /out/ work in Alaska to try and clear my heart and my head. Quit taking Zoloft during this time.

Following this, I left and did a "normal" job for about 1.25 years before I again felt the urge to get the fuck back outside. I worked for an environmental compliance contractor. I had a moment of clarity when a guy who had been there for 12 years told me he had a zoology degree. It made me sad to know he once shared my dreams. So I had to leave. Almost every person I knew told me that, at ~28 it was too late for a "career change" and I should just stay in place and effectively work at the same place until I died. I've since worked for a few different agencies/places for the feds doing /out/ things. I do not make much money. My job security is tenuous. But I feel at peace and wouldn't change it.

The point of my story is simply that if you recognize something you are truly passionate about, you should just stick with it, because trying to convince yourself you are happier in some other capacity just results in you being miserable. I wouldn't do something just to feel like you're moving forward, if that makes sense. I wouldn't do something you aren't "super passionate" about. Do not go be a cop simply because it is SOMETHING. Its your life, anon. 1/4 of it is over. Do you want to waste another 1/2 doing something you don't even give a shit about?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Honestly anything purely chat based or designed for “meeting people” is pretty hopeless, best to start with a shared interest.

If you have a specific hobby or are interested in picking one up, small forums and social media communities work. I’ve made hobby-aligned friends on Twitter just by searching for related terms, replying to replies on big posts, etc. Post and comment actively even if it’s slow to start.

Seconding games with mics, any of the popular FPS. Accept the people who try to add you (or send the reqs) and join them right away. Games with a guild aspect like WoW can be great too but obviously only if you have some interest in the content itself. People feel good about helping new players if you’re just picking something up.

Be chatty and genuine, treat everyone like you’re already friends even if that seems awkward. If you’re playing something with a friends notes function (or just in a doc if you’re hardcore lol) write down who people are and pieces of info you can follow up on next time. Talk about yourself too! It feels a bit orchestrated at first but helps turning pleasant acquaintances into friends especially if you’re coming across a lot of new people at once.

This is all pretty surface level stuff but it’s what works for me :) Don’t let the connections that fizzle out prevent you from keeping on. Good luck!

Some do, some don‘t. If you have an ed, you‘re usually aware and you fluctuate between wanting to get healthy and sane and just surrendering to it. So there might be times you‘ll try to be better with your food, nourish your body and stay away from stuff that triggers you. There might be times where you get preoccupied with something else like having a baby, having a new relationship, losing a loved one or so. But then there might be phases where it kicks in hard again and it‘s all you focus on and you go back down the rabbit hole. And your weight might reflect that. Ofc it‘s not the same for everyone but you don‘t seem to know much about anorexia at all. It‘s not that those people decide to just waste away one day and then they do until they die off. Side effects are minimal for me. Highly recommended if you are legit depressed.

>>28181570
You really don't need a "program", just hit each muscle group 2x a week with good exercises. Set the weight so that you fail around 8-12 reps. Try to add weight to each exercise every week.

I do a 6 day a week PPL, each workout takes around 1-1.5 hours depending on how busy it is. 7 exercises per workout, all sets close to or at failure. I don't do much legs personally, just enough to keep things proportional. Focus on the masculinizing muscles. Delts, Back, Traps, Arms. Some chest too. I also got a harness to do direct neck work since the neckpill is real lol, but thats not necessary.

I wouldnt focus on setting the rep numbers to something specific like 5x5 or 10x3, just going as close to failure as you can within the 8-12 range.

posts.com:
>>28180483
starting all the convos isn't a bad thing, as long as you don't mind it. The social awkwardness goes away with time, just need to increase the volume of time you spend being social. It's great that you engage with the subject even if you don't like it, but try and brainstorm ways that you can redirect to subjects you so that it doesn't tire you out. Try and encourage something active to do while hanging out in person so that it's easier on the social side of things, i.e. have to talk less like imagine if you were playing basketball with friends, don't have to focus on talking the entire time. Try and become more comfortable with silence and extended pauses. And don't worry about being awkward, everyone is a bit awkward if you really look into it, the key is to try and be as lax/chill as you can, don't stress over it. Now if you want people to start the conversations more with you, try and find ways to make yourself more approachable, if it's online for example, try and keep your status online and maybe have a DM friendly message set so that people know it's okay to reach out you, let people know that they're free to message you whenever. Try and find ways to become more interesting, or find something to teach. If you know a skill, you won't run out of people reaching out to you for help like say if you knew a lot about coding, people will always be asking for advice/help on whatever their doing and so on. Good luck anon

I don't think so. I've got diagnosed with Asperger's myself due to a school principal who tried to get rid of me that way by making me qualify for a special-needs school. Interestingly enough, the special schools recommended to my parents were those for intellectually disabled children despite my above-average performance at school.
Based on those questionable principles, the school then forced my parents to get me checked out which unsurprisingly resulted in a diagnosis of atypical autism. A nice way of saying that I met some of the criteria while not actually qualifying for it.
I undiagnosed myself several years ago because the diagnosis did not make sense to me and not necessarily because I didn't share some of those 'autistic' features. There's no use in thinking that your quirks are pathological or wrong if you're not otherwise functioncally limited. And once you're getting older and wiser, you eventually realize that all this talk about 'helping' you with pointless services is really nothing but aggressive marketing.

>>28181104
not too late, you're still have plenty of time, and it's great that you realize this now so you can make the appropriate changes and apply them, the only issue here is to make sure you really put the energy to changing and really want to improve. First thing first, you should get a cheap notebook and pencil/pen, and journal. Reflect your current situation, see what pros you have, negatives, decide what you want to change and why. Set a goal, what do you want to achieve in your new life, be specific and measurable. Make a plan of how you can try and reach these goals, small manageable steps and leave room for failure, not everything will go right at first but you can adapt as you learn. Take action, start with the plan and adjust as needed.
>no friends
try and join clubs in college, anything from dance to juggling, whatever feels easy to get started but remember not to take too seriously, be open to change and new opportunities and the friends will come as you make yourself more present.
>sit at home most of the time on my computer
try and spend more time on your college campus, instead of rushing home, try and stick around, see what events are going on and try to attend them, colleges always have things going on, try and find out what's next, maybe if they have any volunteering events check those out or an on campus cinema to hang out or even just the library. The more time you spend out, away from the computer at home, the more likely you'll gain friends and talk with women. As your situation improves, and you build confidence on your outlook, I'm sure you'll become less arrogant and judgemental. Good luck anon, hope it gets better for you soon!

I need some peace of mind because I feel like I'm getting crazy and angrier at the same time.

I want to point out that within the last year, a year ago just about I have had strange encounters with an SUV that would pass by my house slowly. One time at night, this SUV pulled up by me and nearly stopped. I couldn't see who was in it, but after a bit they kept going, and I swear they went around the block twice. I don't understand why other than to scare me. The one really ingrained in my head though, is when I was smoking weed at the time I went outside at 2am to take a couple hits. At 2am, this SUV came by my house and nearly stopped right in front of my driveway. That startled me and I turned my head super fast towards it like the exorcist and it just went along. I haven't had any occurrences like this since then.

However today, technically yesterday where I live as it's 2am right now, I was taking a walk like I try to every day after work for the exercise. It starts to get darker around 5pm and at around 530 to 545 its pretty dark. Well, it was still clearly light out for the record, dimmer but visible. I was walking on the right side, going down a normal hill, like already down the hill enough that if a car came over they'd clearly see me. I knew a car was coming up from behind me, and I literally felt the wind of the car as if it was inches away from me, and it swerved to avoid me at the last second. I looked back to due anxiety and I just raised my hand like wtf? I kept walking and I got further down and I could hear it coming back a minute or two later this time facing me. My head locked on to it, and they came towards me, as if to clearly run me over but swerved again. As the car passed I turned around and stared at it and the license plate. I forgot it the moment I looked away but I remembered a number and a letter. I took my phone out at that point and I was going to make sure to record it this time.

Buy a tiny notebook, write notes about your anime battles and storylines. Keep a "lore journal". Use it to do worldbuilding. Draw little doodles, no matter how bad, to represent things.

Learn to play tabletop RPGs later, and use them to run a game. Or learn to write and post synopsis of your stories online on a website like ficitonpress.com. If you're not a good writer or you're embarassed about it, make an anonymous email and post them without anybody knowing.

I used to be part of a forum where everyone did this sort of thing and shared their amateur fantasy stories. They were fuckin' cool.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yes you can get banned. You can check 4chan.org/bans to see the posts people have recently been banned for and for how long. Generally it's a 3 day ban for the more common reasons (off topic/trolling/etc), but bans can also be for 7 days, or 30 days which is usually for ban evasion/spam/underage users and stuff like that. Permanent bans are also a thing but those I've only seen given out for posts that break the law or are really aggressive in their spam. Bans that are 3 days or less can not be appealed, but bans longer than that can be appealed every two weeks until you run out of appeals or your ban expires.

The longest I've been banned was for 30 days when I posted something that triggered 4chan's anti-spam system. I appealed it twice and they were both denied so now I'm paranoid about posting links because I think that's what caused it. That's a fluke though. If you aren't stupid you'll be fine.

>>28180801
I'm not a pharmacist or doctor but I work in a related field. Personally, I wouldn't take those. I'll need to see what the pills look like (to confirm they are what's listed), the strength, and what your weight is in order to see how many you would need to take. As they're for fish, they won't be the same strength as the kind normally prescribed. Taking expired medication isn't too bad, but for antibiotics, I'm not sure how viable those pills are now.

In regards to oral abscesses: I had one when I took was in the middle of nowhere and didn't have insurance. A friend told me to swish coconut oil around my mouth for 20mins daily (this is called oil pulling. Spit this out in the trash and NOT in the sink), gargle with warm salt water on the hour every hour, and keep a warm black tea bag on the abscess, preferably overnight too if possible. Cleared it up in a jiffy. However! This is risky. I would recommend that you see a doctor so then it doesn't get potentially worse. Oral health is extremely important and can lead to extreme illness or death if you're not careful.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28174710
Talk to a lawyer. My general thought is, no. If you're profiting off of someone else's copyright the fair use argument will no longer hold water. In fact, from my understanding, profiting off of someone's copyright (even a few pennies) would be enough to move from civil infringement to criminal infringement. This is especially true when you're intentionally infringing. But in all things, talk to a lawyer.
